entry.et: partly from Middle English waken (past wook, past participle waken), from Old English wacan to awake (past wōc, past participle wacen); partly from Middle English wakien, waken (past & past participle waked), from Old English wacian to be awake (past wacode, past participle wacod); akin to Old English wæccan to watch, Latin vegēre to enliven

def.dt: :to be or remain awake
:to remain awake on watch especially over a corpse
:to stay up late in revelry
:awake often used with up
:to stand watch over (as a dead body)
:to hold a wake over
:to rouse from or as if from sleep :awake often used with up
:stir excite woke up latent possibilities Norman Douglas
:to arouse conscious interest in :alert usually used with to woke the public to the risks
:the state of being awake
:an annual English parish festival formerly held in commemoration of the church's patron saint
:vigil 1a
:the festivities originally connected with the wake of an English parish church usually used in plural but singular or plural in construction
:an annual holiday or vacation usually used in plural but singular or plural in construction
:a watch held over the body of a dead person prior to burial and sometimes accompanied by festivity

entry.et: akin to Middle Low German wake wake, Norwegian dialect vok, Old Norse vǫk hole in ice

def.dt: :the track left by a moving body (as a ship) in a fluid (as water)
:a track or path left
:aftermath 3
:close behind and in the same path of travel missionaries arrived in the wake of conquistadors and soldiers Sabine MacCormack
:as a result of :as a consequence of power vacuums left in the wake of the second world war A. M. Schlesinger b1917
:trillium
:jack-in-the-pulpit
:serving to wake up a wake–up alarm
:something (as a telephone call from a hotel employee to a guest) that serves to wake a sleeper
:something that serves to alert a person to a problem, danger, or need a wake-up call to parents
island North Pacific N of Marshall Islands belonging to the United States
